The selective oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) is a key step in C4 oxidation for polymethyl methacrylate production, but the limited catalytic activity of polyoxometalates (POMs) hinders their industrial use. Here, we synthesized POM-IL hybrid catalysts via ion exchange and calcination. Ionic liquids disrupted the POM structure through hydrogen bonding, creating oxygen vacancies that optimized adsorption energy and prevented MAL over-oxidation to COx. The hydrogen bonding between ionic liquids and polyoxometalate anions, coupled with ammonium ions derived from ionic liquids, generated a synergistic effect that markedly improves the acidity and redox properties of the catalyst. The catalyst achieved 82.9 % MAL conversion, 88.9 % MAA selectivity, and exceptional stability over 80 h. In-situ infrared spectroscopy and partial density of states (PDOS) analysis identified Mo=Od as the active site, with ester intermediate formation as the rate-determining step. This study uncovers the influence of hydrogen bonding in ionic liquids on the structure-activity relationship of polyoxometalate anions, offering crucial insights into the mechanism of methacrolein selective oxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Oxygen vacancies Polyoxometalate salts Methacrylic acid Selective oxidation Methacrolein Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methyl methacrylate (MMA) is an important monomer for polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), which is widely used in fields such as optical materials, electronics, displays, and electrical, automotive, and lighting industries [1–4]. However, the current industrial production of MMA using the acetone cyanohydrin (ACH) process involves the use of highly toxic hydrogen cyanide (HCN), posing serious environmental and health risks. Consequently, recent research has focused on developing a cleaner C4 oxidation process to improve environmental sustainability and eliminate harmful substances. The C4 oxidation process consists of three steps: (1) conversion of tert-butanol or isobutene to methacrolein (MAL), (2) oxidation of MAL to methacrylic acid (MAA), and (3) conversion of MAA to MMA. Among these steps, the efficient production of MAA from MAL is crucial to the success of the C4 oxidation process [5–10]. Polyoxometalates, such as phosphomolybdate and phosphomolybdovanadate, are commonly used catalysts in the oxidation of MAL to MAA [11]. However, these catalysts often suffer from drawbacks such as low specific surface area and poor thermal stability, which result in low catalytic efficiency and limited catalytic lifetimes. Research has demonstrated that introducing Cs+ counterions to heteropolyacids enhances both their thermal stability and specific surface area. With increased cesium content, the specific surface area of phosphomolybdate rises from approximately 5 m2/g to over 50 m2/g [12]. Recently, researchers have modified cesium phosphomolybdovanadate salts to further improve their catalytic performance. For instance, Zhang et al. [13] observed that the incorporation of Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions enhanced the catalysts' redox capacity, leading to increased catalytic activity. The addition of NH4 + also modified the structural and catalytic properties of the catalysts. Cao et al. [14] synthesized and characterized a series of Cs(NH4 +)xH3-xPMo11VO40 catalysts with varying ammonium contents. Compared to CsH3PMo11VO40, the introduction of ammonium salts not only increased the specific surface area but also augmented the acidic site density. Additionally, electron transfer was enhanced, facilitating the reduction of V5+ to V4+. This resulted in an increased concentration of the reactive species (VO2+) involved in the MAL oxidation reaction. Li et al. [15] also proposed a novel method to synthesize defective CsH3PMo11VO40 through microwave-assisted precipitation for the oxidation of MAL to MAA. Their findings indicated that microwave treatment accelerated the nucleation rate of the catalyst and promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies. These vacancies improved the oxidative capacity of active Mo species, thereby enabling adsorbed oxygen activation to lattice oxygen, which promoted MAL oxidation [16–18]. Nonetheless, despite enhancements from counterions like Cu2+, Cs+, and NH4 +, the conversion rate of MAL and the selectivity for MAA remain suboptimal [19,20]. Ionic liquids (ILs) are molten salts composed of organic cations and anions. Through double displacement reaction, they can react with POMs to form POM-IL hybrid, a new class of organic-inorganic hybrid materials [21]. POM-IL hybrid exhibit excellent chemical properties and can be utilized in various reactions, including oxidative desulfurization (ODS) [22–26], benzene hydroxylation to phenol [27], and the oxidative conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [28]. Cao et al. [29] successfully synthesized [EMIM]PAVAC, achieving up to 98 % MAA selectivity in MAL oxidation. The generation of NH4 + during calcination could promote the reduction of V5+ to V4+, thus enhancing the redox capacity of the catalyst. Proton migration between the ionic liquid and polyoxometalate anions significantly enhances the catalyst's redox properties and helps form diverse hydrogen bond donors and acceptors. Gao et al. [30] found the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the ionic liquid and polyoxometalate anions can significantly modulate their structural characteristics and catalytic performance. However, systematic studies on the influence of hydrogen bonding effects in ionic liquids on the structure of polyoxometalate salts and their catalytic performance in methacrolein selective oxidation are still lacking. 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hydrogen sulfate, a highly acidic ionic liquid, has been recognized for its ability to efficiently dissolve cellulose in aqueous phases and to exhibit exceptional catalytic performance in various esterification reactions [31–33]. Additionally, this ionic liquid has been demonstrated as an effective additive to modify the crystal structure of electrolytes, significantly improving their overall performance [34,35]. Based on these properties, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hydrogen sulfate was chosen, and a novel POM-IL hybrid catalyst was successfully synthesized using ion exchange and calcination methods. Characterization results revealed that the hydrogen bonding between ionic liquids and POM anions, along with the synergistic effect of ammonium ions derived from the ionic liquid, significantly enhanced the catalyst's acidity and redox properties. Additionally, hydrogen bonding was found to increase the number of oxygen vacancies in POM anions, thereby promoting gaseous oxygen adsorption and enhancing lattice oxygen replenishment.These changes led to a significant enhancement in catalytic activity. In-situ infrared spectroscopy identified the terminal Mo=Od site in the catalyst as the active site for MAL oxidation. DFT calculations revealed that the formation of ester intermediates at the terminal Mo=Od site is the rate-determining step in MAL oxidation. The catalyst achieved an 82.9 % conversion rate of MAL and 88.9 % selectivity for MAA under atmospheric pressure at 310 °C. These findings highlight the POM-IL hybrid catalyst's outstanding performance in MAL oxidation and offer critical insights for the design and application of industrial catalysts. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials All chemicals were employed in their original state without any prior treatment. Methylacrolein (95 wt%), methacrylic acid, molybdenum trioxide (MoO3), acetic acid, vanadium pentoxide (V2O5), phosphoric acid (85 wt%), Ammonium bicarbonate (NH4HCO3), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2), cesium nitrate (CsNO3), and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazole bisulfate ([BMIM]HSO4) were purchased from Aladdin Company. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV) was prepared according to the literature [36]. Initially, 0.004 mol [BMIM]HSO4 was dispersed in deionized water to form solution A. In parallel, 0.004 mol of HPAV was dissolved in deionized water to prepare solution B. Simultaneously, 0.004 mol CsNO3 and 0.0008 mol Cu(NO3)2 were each dissolved in deionized water to form solution C. Then, solution A and C were added sequentially to solution B at 85 °C and stirred vigorously for 6 h continuously. The mixture was subjected to multiple centrifugation and washing cycles. Barium nitrate was then added to the wash solution until no more precipitate formed, indicating the completion of the washing process. Finally, the washed precipitate was dried overnight at 80°C, followed by further calcination at 350 °C for 12 h to obtain the final product, named (NH4 +)XCu0.2CsH4-X-1.2PMo11VO40 (BPAV). The synthesis process is illustrated in Scheme 1. The synthesis methods for Cu0.2CsH2.8PMo11VO40 (CPAV) and (NH4 +)Cu0.2CsH1.8PMo11VO40 (NPAV) are similar to the aforementioned process. The only difference for NPAV is that [BMIM]HSO4 is replaced with NH4HCO3 during the synthesis. All catalysts are pressed and sieved for catalytic testing. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted using a Smartlab 9 kW diffractometer (Japan) to study the crystal phase and crystallinity of the catalyst. The X-ray source was Cu-Kα with a wavelength of 0.15418 nm. The tube current was 100 mA, the tube voltage was 40 kV, and the scanning angle range was 2θ = 5–80°, with a scanning rate of 10°/min. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the sample were collected using a Thermo Nicolet 870 infrared spectrometer. Samples were prepared by mixing and grinding with KBr. They were tested with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 32 scans in the wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1. Diffuse reflection UV–visible (UV–vis) spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV3600 spectrophotometer, tested at 200–800 nm with BaSO4 as the reference. Raman spectra were obtained using a Thermo Fischer DXR with a 100 mV laser and CCD detector. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTA) was carried out on a Rigaku thermal gravimetric analyzer (Japan) to study the structural evolution of the catalyst precursor (15 mg). The sample was heated from room temperature to 600 °C in an alumina crucible at a rate of 15 °C/min under airflow. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) using Zeiss Gemini 300 field. The sample was fixed on the surface of the conductive adhesive and coated with gold. The scanning voltage was usually 5 kV and the scanning current was usually 10 μA. The pore structure of the relevant samples was observed using JEOL 794 transmission electron microscope from Japan. N2 adsorption and desorption were performed using an ASAP 2020 adsorbent instrument from Micromeritics, USA, and the samples were degassed at 180 °C for 4 h prior to measurement. The samples were tested using a PHI-5300 Versa Probe X-ray energy spectrometer (XPS) and Al K α (h) ν = 1486.6 eV monochromatic radiation was used as the radiation source, with an acceleration power of 15 kW. Before measurement, the sample was first processed in an ultra-high vacuum tube. After the test, the binding energy of the standard C1s (284.8 eV) was used for calibration. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectra (ICP-OES) (PerkinElmer 8300) was used to determine the actual amount of P/Mo/V/Cs in the catalyst. An EPR spectrometer (Bruke Emxplus, Germany) was used to perform EPR spectroscopy at room temperature in the X-band mode. The microwave power, resonance frequency, modulation width and time constant were 2 mW, 9.417 GHz, 0.5 mT and 0 s, respectively. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was evaluated using Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument equipped with thermal conductivity detector to assess the acidity of the catalyst. The fact that all atoms were in a relaxed state ensured the accuracy of the calculation of the interaction between the MAL and the catalyst. The generalized gradient approximation of the PBE function was used to measure the exchange correlation energy. The interactions between the nuclei and electrons of metal atoms were calculated by the DSPP method, while other atoms were treated as all-electrons [38]. At the same time, the valence electron function was extended into atomic orbitals with a DNP basis and partial occupancies were calculated by means of 0.005 Hartree smearing value [39]. The adsorption configuration adopted a 2x1x1 Monkhorst Pack lattice. The convergence criteria for structural optimization were: allowable energy of 2 × 10−5 eV/atom, maximum force of 0.05 eV/atom and maximum displacement of 2 × 10−3 atom. The adsorption energy was calculated using the following formula: Eads=EHPAV-MAL-EMAL-EHPAV. The response coordinates were optimized using the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method. In NEB, each image was connected to its neighboring images through harmonic constraints, simulating the effect of an elastic band. The relaxation of the entire band towards the minimum energy path (MEP) was driven by adjusting the spring and atomic forces to ensure they were orthogonal to the reaction path. Force and energy calculations were performed using Grimme's three-modified Hartree-Fock method. Fig. 3a and S10 illustrate that as the temperature increased from 280 °C to 310 °C, the conversion rate of MAL over the BPAV catalyst rose from 68.6 % to 82.9 %. The BPAV catalyst exhibited superior performance compared to other catalysts in both the conversion rate of MAL and the selectivity for MAA (Fig. 3a), demonstrating enhanced catalytic activity across different temperatures. The increase in MAL conversion rate with temperature can be attributed to the participation of more activated molecules in the reaction. However, beyond 310 °C, the generation of by-products intensified, resulting in a decrease in selectivity. The optimal reaction temperature for the BPAV catalyst was determined to be 310 °C, with a conversion rate of 82.9 % and a selectivity of 88.9 %. To investigate the roles of ionic liquids, copper, and vanadium in catalytic reactions, we employed a variable control method to prepare catalysts missing one of the above specific component. As shown in Table S7, compared to the BPAV catalyst, the catalyst (NH4 +)XCsH3-XPMo11VO40 lacking copper ions exhibited a significant decrease in both conversion rate and selectivity. This is likely because Cu2+/Cu+ ions can accelerate the electron transfer rate between the Keggin-type heteropolyacid anion structure, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity in the MAL reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst (NH4 +)XCu0.2CsH3-X-1.2PMo12O40 showed lower catalytic activity compared to other vanadium-containing catalysts. Based on the in situ IR spectroscopy analysis and related literature [5,15], the mechanism for the selective oxidation of MAL to MAA over the BPAV catalyst is proposed (Fig. 5d) and the whole reaction pathway in conjunction with DFT calculations (Fig. 5c) is explained. In an acidic environment, the carbonyl carbon atom of MAL first breaks and adsorbs onto the terminal Mo=Od of the heteropolyacid anion containing an oxygen vacancy, forming the M1 structure. In the TS1 stage, the C-H bond in the MAL molecule breaks, weakening the strength of the terminal Mo=Od, while the carbonyl carbon of MAL begins to undergo reconstruction. The Gibbs free energy required for this step is 68.85 kcal/mol. Subsequently, the broken hydrogen atom migrates to another position of the terminal Mo=Od, forming an O-H bond and contributing to the creation of the intermediate ester group M2. This transition has a Gibbs free energy of 66.88 kcal/mol, which is considered the rate-determining step of the reaction. Next, the oxygen atom in the terminal Mo=Od breaks and combines with hydrogen atoms to form the target product MAA. The Gibbs free energy requirement for this process is 24.97 kcal/mol. The oxygen vacancies further adsorb gaseous oxygen, leading to the breakage of the O-O bond in the oxygen molecule at the oxygen vacancies and replenishing of the oxygen atoms into the lattice, forming lattice oxygen. The Gibbs free energy of this step is 24.33 kcal/mol. After completing the above cycle, the catalyst returns to its pristine state M5. 4 Conclusion In this study, polyoxometalate-ionic liquid catalysts were successfully synthesized through ion exchange followed by calcination. The incorporation of ILs weakened the structural integrity of the polyoxometalate anions via hydrogen bonding, leading to the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. These vacancies provided ideal adsorption energy, effectively preventing the over-oxidation of MAL to COx. The synergistic interaction between the hydrogen bonding of ionic liquids with POM anions and the NH4 + ions generated during pyrolysis plays a key role in enhancing the acidity of BPAV. Under atmospheric pressure and at a reaction temperature of 310 °C, the developed catalyst exhibited exceptional performance, achieving an MAL conversion rate of 82.9 % and MAA selectivity of 88.9 %, while maintaining outstanding stability over 80 h of continuous operation. Moreover, in-situ infrared spectroscopy and PDOS analysis confirmed that the terminal Mo=Od site was the primary active site for MAL oxidation. Reaction pathway calculations indicated that the formation of an ester intermediate at Mo=Od is the rate-determining step. This work systematically explores the impact of hydrogen bonding in ionic liquids on the structure-performance relationship of polyoxometalate anions and further enhances our understanding of the mechanism behind the selective oxidation of methacrolein. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) is a key step in C4 oxidation for polymethyl methacrylate production, but the limited catalytic activity of polyoxometalates (POMs) hinders their industrial use. Here, we synthesized POM-IL hybrid catalysts via ion exchange and calcination. Ionic liquids disrupted the POM structure through hydrogen bonding, creating oxygen vacancies that optimized adsorption energy and prevented MAL over-oxidation to COx. The hydrogen bonding between ionic liquids and polyoxometalate anions, coupled with ammonium ions derived from ionic liquids, generated a synergistic effect that markedly improves the acidity and redox properties of the catalyst. The catalyst achieved 82.9 % MAL conversion, 88.9 % MAA selectivity, and exceptional stability over 80 h. In-situ infrared spectroscopy and partial density of states (PDOS) analysis identified Mo=Od as the active site, with ester intermediate formation as the rate-determining step. This study uncovers the influence of hydrogen bonding in ionic liquids on the structure-activity relationship of polyoxometalate anions, offering crucial insights into the mechanism of methacrolein selective oxidation.
